positive.review:
Wow! Where do i even start?

My husband surprised me with a new PC and the first thing i download from stream is this game , Inzoi ! I know thier is still updates and bugs to fix  but So far i have been loving it! I am a huge fan of sims 4 BUT this is a whole new level ! This game satisfied my craving for creativity and control. The graphics BLEW ME away my expectations , like everything looks insanely beautiful and lifelike, from the city streets to the stunning Zoi themselves! I don't even need mods to edit my Zoi ! If you need to download mods its so convenient ! (anyone who plays Sims 4 for years knows what im talking about.)

Highly recommend for anyone passionate in building and Character Creation! I think Inzoi offers a beautiful sandbox for simulation lovers with focus on creative possibilities, community management , and photorealistic design, though on going updates promise even deeper gameplay and social complexity. I am excited what comes next !

Honestly, InZoi feels like a dream come true. The shoulder-view perspective alone already makes it feel so real, and then there‚Äôs running around via WASD, driving vehicles manually, and just exploring the open world. It‚Äôs crazy how immersive it all feels.

The graphics are absolutely insane, like every little detail makes you want to stop and take screenshots. It‚Äôs the kind of game that makes you forget time exists.

Can‚Äôt wait to see what future updates bring. This is easily one of the most exciting gaming experiences I‚Äôve had in a long time.
Its like The Sims, but no micro transactions, no hacking and its still in development. Nice to play when I just want to manage a house for fun.

This game needs a lot more love poured into it before it's at the same level as some other life sims, but I think it's worth giving it a try. The gameplay is still a little clunky but I think it has some really creative ideas and I appreciate that the first DLC was released for free. I'm honestly a little shocked that pets aren't included but will eagerly await their arrival.
Amazing game, wish for it to receieve more progress in the times to come!

inZOI is a promising modern life-simulation game ‚Äî and it immediately catches your eye. It offers impressive character and world customization, high-quality visuals, and the kind of freedom that life-sim fans will appreciate.

What I like the most:
- The character creation and world building are really strong ‚Äî lots of options, plenty of creativity.
- The graphics and environment show big potential ‚Äî the engine, the details, the atmosphere all feel premium.
- The developers are committed to updates and support, which is a big plus for future growth.

That said ‚Äî there are some important caveats:
- The game is still in Early Access, meaning some core mechanics are missing or not fully polished ‚Äî which may affect some players.
- The depth of character interaction and expected life-sim content aren‚Äôt quite at the level of the best in the genre yet.
- If your PC is not very strong, you might face performance issues ‚Äî the game demands a bit to run smoothly.

üí¨ In summary:
inZOI is definitely worth keeping an eye on ‚Äî it has the potential to become a standout life sim for fans who enjoy games like The Sims 4. But if you're looking for a fully finished, polished experience right now, you might want to wait until content and mechanics are more refined.

Rating - 8.5/10‚≠ê
A strong start with huge potential. It‚Äôs now up to the developers to make good on it.

I guess I'll start by saying that I am a die-hard Sims fan. I grew up playing that game, and still play it to this day. 

When I saw the release for inZOI, it peaked my curiosity and I wondered how a game with similar mechanics to the Sims could possibly compete to the game I was so biased about, lol. I bought and played inZOI pretty much right after it released to the public.

 I love the graphics, and how you can move your character with WASD. I love building houses for my little made up characters, and inZOI definitely has this on lockdown for it's players. They have the 3D printing option, people are able to add their creations through "CANVAS", and that just shows how inZOI is being more open to community creations directly integrated into their game than the Sims (where your CC/mods break with every update?!). Guess what, I dont have that issue with inZOI! You can definitely create and customize your Zoi's and make them whoever your imagination wants to create, build and decorate houses, and play god with your Zoi's life, including career, relationships, and daily activities! They do not have pets yet, but I am waiting for that! They added a DLC that has a bit more interactive gameplay and if they keep adding things like this to the game, then they're definitely on the right track. I would definitely say I love this game as much as The Sims, as this game has amazing potential.

I like everything about this game. The only change I would make is to change when you are texting other people to be able to text other people whenever you want and to have more options for what to be able to text them!
Honestly it's pretty good in its concept, but might need more times for the developers for providing better gaming experience.
Basically The Sims on crack. If you grew up off the Sims and enjoyed them, This game comes highly recommended. Fits that same Niche with so much more epxanding from those original life building games
Still does not beat Sims 4 in any way, shape or form. But it still a beautiful game, good visuals, up-to-date mechanics. Modding is okay, character customization is pretty good.
I like the game. The graphics are great and it has lots of potential, but it still needs more time, for more things to get added, for more variety in general.

10/10 would recommend. its so much fun to create and play with my zoi, detail over the city and in characters, the story you can create and history recorded... just all over everything I have ever personally wanted from the sims. Im so excited to see all the updates and what this game brings in the future. I hope to see more ability with more tattoos being placed on your zoi, mods definitely help but sadly take away from other jewelry your zoi can wear. I also would like to see more household things and child toys and such just felt a bit sad / repetitive in the kids room with certain aspects.. otherwise amazing game and absolutely a new favourite!

Please note that I'm just still a beginner living off youtube channels for help. I love this game so far. There are so many options, I was first overwhelmed, but once I watched a few beginners tutorials, I figured out how to navigate the screens...now I'm in love with the options this game has to offer. I have been playing it for over 50 hrs so far and have barely noticed the glitches and have not once thought I need mods to make the game better. I love the presets, it makes creating Zois easy for someone like me. So far, I've just been playing random scenarios (no big generational game started yet:P). I know there are endless presets available, I have not figured out how to go get them yet. That's next on my list of stuff to learn. 
I had difficulty with driving lol. It's not as easy as it looks. Since I bough this game last week, I've noticed it changed twice. I feel like it's being updated live as I play it. My suggestion is to be patient, the changes have made menus easier to navigate. 
I feel like I've been waiting for this game for years! I have been watching my husband play games like GTA and kept wanting that game, but with me controlling it like I do with the Sims... I feel like Inzoi has been the answer to my wish.

I'm just posting a review to help the dev out. There's been some hilariously overblown and overdramatized articles from games sites on inZoi, trying to spin lack of active players into lack of success. It's not am MMO shooter, player numbers don't mean whack.
 like me, the vast majority bought it because they believe in what the devs are trying to achieve. and like me, the vast majority have the brains to understand what "early access" means. We're waiting and letting KRAFTON work their magic. Expecting the title to have as much versatility and depth as a game series with 20+ years of experience before full release is a bit idiotic imho.
What‚Äôs going on? Why do we always have problems with the Canvas downloads after every game update? This is really annoying! Please fix this issue.‚Äù
its Alright. its Lack of "something" if you what i mean,....this not a sims 4 killer yet. still in beta, give em a chance. but,...still lacking Features.

Loving this game so far. They've got excellent communication, responsive teams to bugs that occur, and continuously push out free content as the game goes through development. 

While they still have a ways to go in terms of diverse, expansive gameplay elements, the foundation they do have is incredibly innovative and strong. I absolutely love the clothing designer, and the online elements like Canvas that make it so I can download others creations - and share mine. The tools make it both easy to be discovered and easy to find what I'm looking for. 

I look forward to when they add things like pets, gardening, and basements. In the meantime, I love that you can change almost every texture in the game and even upload your own. It's so satisfying having all the door handles in the house match the same metal of the stove, lamps, etc. and similarly, having all the wood furniture the exact same texture and color. They truly put a lot of thought into the building mode (even though it took me a long time to learn! It's way more powerful than other games, just not as intuitive).  

Cheers to this team and looking forward to more <3

Inzoi is a gorgeous game with immense potential, but in its current early access state, the simulation lacks the depth and objective to be replayable.

Pros:
- Stunning Visuals - incredibly realistic graphics and detailed character models
- Open World Potential - The large, open cities provide an immersive setting with many buildings to visit.

Cons:
- Lack of Depth - Hobbies, careers and relationships need more substance. The personality traits have minimal impact on actual gameplay.
- Performance - To experience the game's impressive photorealism, you need a powerful PC
- User Interface Issues - difficult to navigate, hard to find options you need

InZOI is a really impressive next-gen life simulation game that stands out for its stunning visuals and high level of customization. It delivers exceptionally detailed characters, expressive animations, and richly crafted environments that feel far more lifelike than most games in the genre. The highlight is its deep creation tools: you can fine-tune facial features, body types, fashion, interior design, and even entire neighborhoods with remarkable precision. The game also gives you flexible control over characters‚Äô actions, personalities, and social interactions, making each scenario feel dynamic and cinematic.

I‚Äôve played InZoi for about 9.8 hours now, and it‚Äôs been a really cozy experience. The game is still early in development, so some of the life-sim depth isn‚Äôt there yet. NPCs can be a little awkward and there aren‚Äôt a ton of activities, but I never felt annoyed, it honestly feels like watching a wholesome little world slowly take shape. Since I weren't following the development of this game, at this moment I will leave a positive review BUT it's not a good game yet and I have heavy doubts it ever will be.

It feels like a bunch of Unreal Tech Demos glued together, without much substance of a game, which brings a question about development priorities and roadmap. Like consider these tech gimmicks that sound very cool and this game indeed has:
sLM for character thought? It's too small, too weak, and useless as it's not capabe of some MCP / structured output for actually making your character do something. So it just cooks your computer periodically to spit some random nonsence about what just happened with a Zoi. It could be fun to read the end-of-day report that Zois do, but it's just a flavored description of the day. What's the use of it really? Was it important? Since it's experimental and active development, IS it important? Don't get me wrong, I'm quite happy to see that thing running locally in a videogame, but it should be a flavoring, not the dish. I understand and kinda support "AI bad" train, but this is literally on your puter for your entertainment AI - practically the single good use case.
FaceID tracking? Amazing, creating detailed character while moving your own face brings some joy. But there's absolutely no need in that. It's not a multiplayer game, it's cool for photo mode I guess, but I really don't see why focus on this?
Driving? Honeslty I had a great laugh when I accidentally hit a car on my bike and died after ragdolling, I absolutely did not expect that for a sims-like game. But the city is small, traffic is laggy as hell, the physics is lame and driving is literally a chore. Why? I guess it's easy to slap some Unreal plugin that's why, but like it's not making it better at all. Do it right or don't do it, it's NOT needed for the game like this.
Built in DALL-E (I think) is cool for some textures since generally game is low on content, though I admit the existing content feels more quality. This is the first tech gimmick I can understand, but still, was it more important than that little gameplay thingy? It's local and seems to be oblivious enough about popular culture to believe it's actually reinforced on open data, again, it's not "AI bad" case here, what they do is practically a guideline on how it should be done.
Building is kinda fun but very much limited and floor/street decoration is weird. I like the grid better than Sims though. Character editor is quite nice too.

But the game, like actual gameplay is incredibly undercooked. It feels like they jump on the next big thing every time without actually making the game, and by the time they return to the core mechanics everyone won't give a damn about the game already. No depth in characters, no interactions, goals values and passions are kina weird and feel useless, city parameters are kinda cool but again what do they do really, there's no "bad" in this game it's too toothless for that to be useful.

That all leads to big expectations in set up and inevitable disappointment that most of the things in this game are stubs, placeholders. Things break left and right, oftentimes funny, but there's no feeling of acheivement, no reward in this game, no substance, no pleasant surprise.

Let's hope I'm wrong and all that will turn into something good later. I will keep positive attitude and check it again later.

Reading the reviews prior to this made me think twice, but after buying this and playing more than the refund time of 2 hours and dealing with the anomalous mess that is performance, I recommend this game. 

InZOI has a lot of things that give it more replayability over the entire Sims franchise. 
One example are its AI features, such as AI Build and 3D Print. Albeit a bit wonky in its creations, it proves to be a very fun and interesting niche in its application, giving the game almost endless possibilities in design for all 3 levels; character, house and world.

That being said, there is a noticeable learning curve if you just came from the Sims franchise like me, but it's pretty easy to grasp, and quite fascinating as to how in-depth the interactions, animations and designing are. The graphics are absolutely amazing at ultra settings and with raytracing on. Even with some tweaks, even high and medium look leagues better, if not, on-par with other adult games, and far beyond the most modded Sims setup. 

It is however, NOT recommended if you have an office PC or some 2010 and before gaming desktop/laptop, you will probably cook your setup without any chance of repair. It is *very* GPU intensive.

If you're expecting a somewhat finished product with no glitches, kinks or sudden performance degradation, do not buy it now, wait until official release. 

If you're expecting this to be the average "early access" slop game, you're going to be amazed by the potential and the current state of the game. A decade's worth of content is coming out for this game alone, so it's worth that 44 dollars with tax price, especially with all DLC being free. Have fun!

inZOI is... difficult to review, and even more difficult to categorise. But there is a point to my rambling so please bear with me.

For 25+ years the life simulation genre has been dominated by a single entity: The Sims. The original Sims game released by Maxis in 2000 arguably created the genre. It was a risky venture at a time when studios doubted the market for a game without a pre-defined story or objectives.

This was followed by The Sims 2 in 2004, which brought a rotatable camera and 3D world and then The Sims 3 in 2009 which introduced a groundbreaking (if technically demanding) open world. However, The Sims 4's launch in 2014 was notoriously bad. Missing core features like toddlers, pools, and lot rotation among many others lead EA to give away The Sims 2 Ultimate Collection (upon Sims 2 base game installation code verification) as a distraction from the backlash.

Now I am aware that by consistently comparing inZOI to The Sims I risk sounding like a broken record. Yet, the comparison is necessary because The Sims 1-3 didn't just dominate the genre; they WERE the genre for at least 2x generations of players.
______
However, it is crucial to state this plainly: inZOI IS NOT A DIRECT COMPETITOR TO THE SIMS.
______

The Sims franchise for all it's quirks and flaws (including Sims 4's its indoor rain) has always been targeted at a broad audience. This is a series that for commercial purposes often prioritised accessibility over technical ambition. The Sims 3 was a 32-bit game, capping its adjustable ram at 8 GB even as 64-bit systems were becoming standard, solely to ensure it could run on lower-end systems. The philosophy is simple, if The Sims is the only game you play, you'll invest all your gaming budget into its ecosystem.

This brings us to the first and most significant divider: System requirements

inZOI's minimum PC requirement is a NVIDIA RTX 2060 with 6 GB VRAM and 12 GB system RAM. Its recommended specs is an RTX 3070 with 16 GB system RAM. With a 2060 retailing for around $288 and a 3070 Ti easily exceeding $600 (before the rest of the PC components), the financial barrier to entry is immense. The average Sims player simply cannot afford to play inZOI, which automatically distinguishes it from being a true competitor.

So, what is inZOI in its current state? Right now, it functions primarily as a an "Instagram game". It is a stunningly beautiful sandbox for posing your Zoi at a plethora of of scenic, pre-set locations. The goal is a staged, "perfect" realism, and in this, the game is unarguably successful. Its visual presentation is nothing short of breathtaking.

However, this pursuit of realism exposes the current shortcomings in its simulation:
* Poor Path-finding: NPC's and your Zoi frequently struggle with navigation, often walking over objects unless you take manual control.
* Shallow Autonomy: Autonomous interactions are underdeveloped. A Zoi might say one sentence to an NPC before abruptly wandering off to greet someone else.
* Repetitive Skill Building: Improving skills feels like a shore. For example, reading requires finding pre-spawned books in book cases and involves a fixed, timed action rather than a continuous activity.
* Cumbersome Travel: Autonomous vehicle driving is incredibly slow, book-ended by loading screens (though manual driving avoids this). Vehicles and NPC's also have a tendency to pop into existence directly in front of the player.
____________

InZOI is a visually striking game whose extraordinarily realistic graphics are a double-edged sword. This forces players to scrutinise the depth of its life simulation more critically. Every aspect; from your Zoi's behaviour to their interactions with neighbours, is held to a higher, more demanding standard. Unlike the stylised, "whimsical" worlds of The Sims and other cosy games, inZOI's hyper-realism offers no hiding place for its current mechanical imperfections. Its ambition is its greatest strength, but also the source of its most intense scrutiny.

For now, no. Why? It feels lifeless. Although I understand the vision and I know it is in early access, but gameplay-wise, I think at least it should be in beta phase.

Felt inclined to write a review because the game feels like a cash grab and nothing else.

This is where I give up. The game won‚Äôt launch anymore. Followed troubleshooting instructions, made sure GPU drivers are up-to-date. Even ended up wiping and re-downloading everything just in case. No luck.

I could write an essay detailing the clunky, frustrating interactions, and how there's too much repetitive busywork, while lacking genuine simulation. But that would be pointless at this point.

Edit/update: The game runs again after switching from Windows 10 to Linux. Yes, really.

As for the gameplay, I gave it a fair chance, but it isn't for me. I wish to populate a city with my NPCs, and set them loose without constant micromanagement of the mundane. You know, to see what happens: what do they do with their lives, who hooks up with whom, children growing up and moving out on their own volition. Inzoi doesn't really allow that kind of gameplay, and I doubt that‚Äôs going to change.

For example, relationships won't advance to the next level without player intervention. Nobody gets married unless you make it happen yourself. On the other hand, ruining relationships seems to be an important part of Zoi autonomy. How fun.

Babysitting adults who don't take care of their basic needs in a timely manner is neither interesting nor enjoyable. An update added homework for the workers, resulting in even more busywork.

Early on, I created a multi-generational family. After switching to another household for a while, I came back to discover grandpa had knocked up grandma. Yes, it seemed funny at first, but then the game truly bugged out. It was quite distressing to witness a child in the house whose needs and very existence were ignored by everyone. It's probably been fixed since then, but it makes one wonder what people normally do in these kinds of games when something so fundamental can be overlooked during development.

On a more positive note, Inzoi provides a solid dollhouse. The character creator is excellent, and the house editor isn‚Äôt half-bad either. One might get their money's worth just by playing around with those basic game features, ignoring the lacking interactions by playing as a single hermit who works from home.

[h2]General Impressions[/h2]
A [b]life simulation[/b] game where, in my observation, the story unfolds very stiffly - and only for your own character.
You can give your Sim all possible traits, but they barely affect anything. In the end, you create a nice-looking shell.
[b]Will this be improved after EA? Unlikely.[/b]

[h2]Customization[/h2]
Pleasant but [b]limited[/b]. Body sliders barely change anything, and it's not always clear what each one does - pull the wrong way and you end up with a Frankenstein.
Skills seem diverse, but in practice offer little to do. It feels like they created the "meat" of the system but forgot to add any "flavor".

[h2]Daily Life and Character Behavior[/h2]
Cooking exists, but you can't prepare multiple servings (or I just didn't find how). After cooking, the character [b]automatically starts eating[/b], and you can't disable it.
Conversations between characters are mostly fake variety. There are many dialogue options, but they all mean the same thing: "Talk, talk, talk."
Some compare this game to The Sims, but the only real similarity is the [b]pushy behavior of other characters[/b], who constantly interrupt you and break your task queue.

[h2]Canvas and User Content[/h2]
The Canvas platform works, and yes, there's content there.
But [b]there are almost no filters[/b], and finding something specific is frustrating. Everything just drowns in chaos.

[h2]Bugs and Optimization[/h2]
Plenty of small (and not-so-small) bugs.
The interaction system works poorly when objects overlap. Click on a plate, and the game decides you meant the table. Menus disappear if you move the cursor a little too far.

And of course, [b]everyone's always hungry[/b]. Your Sim eats, and an hour later they're starving again. Half the city walks around thinking about food.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
inZOI [b]could have been a great life simulator[/b], but right now it's an empty shell filled with meaningless mechanics.
There's more and more content, but [b]no real depth[/b].
Optimization is poor, and honestly, it's hard to believe it will ever be fixed.

Currently, this is a no from me. I have 2,000 hours in the Sims 4 (yes, I'm that guy) and was looking for something that scratched the same itch, but was different: more polished, modern and realistic. 

Inzoi certainly is more modern and realistic, but then perhaps an excess of that is its problem. The whole experience felt unnervingly...empty. Like living in a soulless, ultra-capitalist universe where basically the people just live to work and make money, and very little happens that is truly moving and meaningful. It felt unpleasantly similar to real life. 

I didn't knowingly or deliberately engage with the AI features at all, but I do also wonder whether AI's centrality to Krafton's whole design philosophy is part of the problem here. The sheer identikit *sameness* of everything, the same "oh look another IKEA sofa" vibe, the same conversations with every single person about what seems to be a completely random, low-quality, computer-generated series of conversation topics. 

What made the Sims 4 great -- yes, janky and buggy mess that it is -- is its heart, its whimsicality, and the knowledge that there is actually a human design team there who are trying to come up with new (and often hilarious) things that will excite the player on a human level. 

Whereas so much of Inzoi just feels...the same. Every day the same, really. Events are put into your Zoi's diary to give the world a sense of being alive, but why you would go to any of these events is anyone's guess, because it's more of the same: standing around in a different pretty backdrop, not really engaging in collaborative experiences, but just waiting to "praise the joy of being alive / discuss the future of artificial intelligence / say there is a cat only you can see" with some rando until you get bored and leave. 

(My constructive criticism here: please please delete the entire social interactions menu, and start the whole thing again from the ground up, preferably using human beings to actually write human conversation).

I am still keeping my eyes on this game. The specs to run it are intense and I have been following the updates, and I really want a viable market competitor to the Sims to succeed. But the new "AI first" policy is *literally the problem with the game right now*: its soullessness, its inauthenticity, its same-ness and lack of character. On that level it feels quite dystopian to play, precisely because it feels to me like being fed so much of the identikit rubbish that we already have to put up with every day. Inzoi, currently, might be the most realistic life Sim out there, but that might be its weakness rather than its strength.

When I first heard of InZoi, I got so excited. As a long-time Sims player, I love seeing devs come up with their own versions of life-sims and I'm always interested in seeing their approach on these types of games. 

With the Sims, you get to build an entire virtual life for yourself, a character you have an attachment to, etc. I thought InZoi would take that and turn it into something more realistic, and it did to some extent, but sadly it was not what I expected or hoped for.

InZoi looks wonderful on the surface and the character creation is honestly the best I've seen in these types of games. It's so detailed and so beautiful in every sense! However, unless you're someone who thoroughly enjoys the visual appeal over actual gameplay and the game being immersive to the point where you can get a bit lost in it, the game loses it's substance very, very quickly. To me, the game lacks emotion and the zois feel a bit robotic... Time moves a lot slower, giving the game that more realistic feel but it doesn't feel like a life sim to me. It feels more like a massive sandbox test for people to create models and watch them move around for experimental purposes. The world is gorgeous, the architecture is incredible, the environment and every other visual aspect in this game is stunning beyond belief, but I can't bring myself to spend more than the hours I already have on this game. 

If you're someone who loves to create, build, and experiment with mods, then this game is probably right up your alley. If you're someone like me who prefers to feel like you can immerse yourself fully and get lost in your imagination through life sims, then I'd say try a different game OR if you're caught by the graphics and visuals, maybe wait until it goes on sale to give it a try. Who knows, maybe you'll have a better experience than me.

This isn't a jab at Krafton or anything btw. I love their creative approach and the way they are constantly communicating with their players to improve the game, but it's just not for me. At least not right now. Even with the recent AI announcement, I still hope for great things in the future.

The game, while fun, needs a lot of improvement in terms of its stability. After trying to troubleshoot dozens of times the constant crashing I had been getting whenever trying to run the game, I discovered that, basically, everytime I have to run the game, I have to delete the settings file (the"GameUserSettings.ini" 
and "GameContentsUserSettings.ini" files located in C:\Users\$UserName\AppData\Local\BlueClient\Saved\Config\Windows), clear the cache, AND compile the shaders, otherwise, the game would just crash to desktop. 

It's a hassle since just compiling the shaders takes about 15 minutes, and I have to do that troubleshooting process I mentioned above  every single time I want to play this game.

What's even more disappointing is that the game wasn't like this before (for context, I had gotten this game since release, and I even got to play the game normally for months without it crashing before getting to the title screen, until the recent Halloween update was released).

As such, I do not recommend the game in its current state. While performance seems to have improved since the update, the game is just not that stable right now.

The Sims franchise needs competition with games like inZOI and Paralives.

The Good: In my opinion inZOI shows a lot of promise at early access. WASD character movement is an underrated and greatly welcomed addition to the life-sim genre. Freeroam is another feature that is great to see in inZOI when compared to The Sims, which has excluded this feature in their latest installment when compared to its predecessors. Hopefully, Krafton can continue to improve and add features that the community wants such as more interactions with the world and the ZOIs. 

The bad: In it's current state, inZOI has beautiful scenery, character models, and objects, but suffers from a lack of interact-ability with the world, resulting in a sterile experience. To address this, Krafton could implement increasing the interactions ZOIs have with their careers, with other ZOIs, with objects, and with the world around them. 

The ugly: Generative AI is not something to celebrate or commend in inZOI nor the video game industry. It will remain as a major flaw in an otherwise promising game until it is removed.
